segments.text: And he said that, I've just made a deal with a brilliant theoretical physicist by the name of Dimitris Nanopoulos.
And he comes from Wisconsin, a Greek.
And he said, boy, he's really something.
In fact, he was also one of the 12 potential Nobel laureates.
He had been cited so many times.
There was a scientific American citing.
He says that he's willing to come to A&M to be a theoretical physicist.
His wife came down the other day.
She looked around and she said, no way.
What am I going to do?
I said, I don't know.
Send him his wife down here.
Maybe I'll show him around.
Maybe we'll figure out something.
So I'll get Russ, she'll get Ruth.
We encourage them by how you can work with our coroner.
So she came down and said, OK, I'll live in the woodland.
But I'm not going to say a conversation, period.
I'm just telling you what went on.
And therefore, they hired him.
And he had been working with us, working with A&M.
He goes up there.
band goes up there twice a week and he teaches, you know, and does that.

That's why it can work with College Station, because it's, you know, you get the cultural base of Houston, and yet you're kind of in between, about an hour and twenty minutes away or thirty minutes away.
And I think that if we get the Aggie Express, it'd be closer.
We're trying to work on that, too.
But that's an example of how we can work with these universities.
In geotechnology, I know enough about the jobs of the nation, what we have to do.
that I think that there's certain things that we can do together that would probably find cash directly.
And you still have to drill it well and be successful 90% of the time, or 50% of the time.
One thing you said earlier was that the oil industry really has never engaged in the kind of research and development activities.
No, but let me say this.
We've got something else that's developing pretty quick, too.
But anyway, I know that we can do that.
But the thing is this, we don't have the top
theoretical geophysicists of the world here in any of those four universities.
That didn't make sense to me.
But all the industries here, they would work with us to help make these people really, really get ahead.
So in the tenure, we'd do something.

Now, we just put together, after the National Problem Council recommendation about three years ago, and I've been working a year and a half doing it, I finally got 23 companies, major companies and major research companies, to agree to go together to do research with heart.
And that focus, that DOE is supposed to match us in dollars.
So now we're trying to put that, it's been a terrible effort to put it together, but I finally got to 23, I'm only at 25, I think.

Major companies, independents, Slumber J, service companies, and now for the first time, we think we might have some chance that, driven by the private sector, matching money between DOE and the private sector, to be run by HARC, but mainly work with the university and with everything.
Now, that's the type of thing that Hart can do.
See, this is what we're trying.
This is the way we're trying to save Hart.
Create those structures, those consortia.
A structure, that consortia, that way the privacy.
Because Houston is going to be the most dynamic town in the Southwest.
I know that.
Dallas is good, but Houston's going to be the best.
Don't tell them that, but I said that.
However, how do we make this thing not only for the benefit of Houston, Texas, but the nation?
That's what I think Hart can do.
That would be something.
That is.
That's an exciting world you've been living in and building.
But I think that all these things have a great deal of promise, and Joe and all of them are interested in it, and I've got a lot of feedback from others.
Well, I think everybody is.
That's one thing.
We found a great deal of unanimity in the enthusiasm and the dedication, I think.
Well, anyway, I'm anxious to see what you all get put together.
Well, thank you, sir.
We really appreciate your time.
